title: Top Plymouth hotel 'devastated' after zero food hygiene rating
text:

Bosses at Plymouth's historic Duke of Cornwall Hotel say they are "devastated" after being given the lowest possible food hygiene rating and stressed they are now spending thousands of pounds on a new kitchen. Management said the inspection came at a time when they had begun but not finished the kitchen refit and they will apply for a reinspection and are confident of gaining a much higher score.
They said inspectors from Plymouth City Council 's food safety team had returned twice since the inspection on March 25 and were happy with the improvements. It is not unusual for the hotel to serve hundreds of meals a day, to staying guests, corporate events and pre-show meals for audiences at Theatre Royal Plymouth and the Pavilions.
Bosses stressed the kitchen is large enough to handle the demand for food while its £41,000 renovation is ongoing. The facility will end up with a new floor, ceiling and equipment, some of which has already arrived.
General manager Quinton O'Shea said: "We are all disappointed and upset. We had a refurbishment programme scheduled anyway but that has now moved ahead dramatically. This month the kitchen will be done.
"The inspectors have been here twice since and are happy for us to operate. Everything picked up in the original visit is being dealt with."
The Millbay Road hotel, which dates from 1863, had previously been given a food hygiene rating of four. The March inspection rated food handling as "good" and management of food safety as "generally satisfactory".
